Natural Methods of Boosting the Immune System

Alex Williamson
Mar 16

On Thursday evening I was sat on the sofa at home. Something didn’t feel quite right. Then it clicks… it’s the feeling of cold and flu symptoms creeping up on me. My head is starting to feel dull, and congested, there’s a slight ache in my limbs. Great, just what I need. The weekend is almost here and I was looking forward to enjoying time with my wife and kids, before another brutally busy work at week in the run up to one of the most important annual events for my business. Not a great time to be getting sick.

The good news is that I’ve been here before. Rather than complain and fall into the suffering and malaise of illness, I prefer to take control. And not like most people. You won’t find me going to the doctor or looking to pharmaceuticals as a cure. In fact there are a number of natural methods that I undertake consistently, that boost your immune system, minimising the risk of illness, and fighting illness off more efficiently when it does occur. I rarely get ill and when I do it doesn’t keep me out of action for long. In fact, I’m about to head off bouldering with my son! What follows are the methods I use to boost my immune system and contribute to my overall health and wellbeing.

Drink a Lot of Water and Stay Hydrated

You should always stay hydrated. Whilst staying hydrated is ultra important when you are ill, I’d also like to highlight the fact that it is very important on a day to day basis[1]. Your body is predominantly made up of water and needs to maintain hydration levels to function at optimal levels. When you get sick you can tend to get dehydrated. This can be due to your bodily functions working hard to fight of illness. A high fever, sweating, vomiting and diarrhea will all contribute to dehydration. Stay properly hydrated so that your body is in the best state possible to fight of the illness.

If you want some additional benefit then add some fruit, such as lemon, to your water for an added kick of vitamin C. Whilst vitamin C supplementation may not actually prevent illness, studies do suggest that it is worth taking vitamin C to reduce the effects of illnesses such as the common cold[2]. Quite frankly there is very little reason not to get a good quality and quantity of vitamins and minerals through natural sources. There is only upside! I’m rarely to be found without my water bottle, and it’ll usually have a slice of lemon in it!

I love water but a bit of variety can be nice. Especially when it offers additional benefits. Tea is one such option. Consider the likes of sage, ginger, lemon, liquorice root, slippery elm, and green tea which have been shown to help sooth congestion and a sore throat. Turmeric team has potential benefits in reducing inflammation, and is a good option for those with inflamed sinuses or mucus membranes. In summary, drinking plenty of water is the number one thing you should do the second you start to feel unwell (and really at all times). Adding natural fruits, herbs and spices will only add further value.

A Healthy Diet and Natural Supplements

A good diet is one of the primary keys for general health and wellness. Fundamentally it ensures your body is getting the fuel it needs to function property. That means getting high quality macro and micro nutrients. It’s all pretty basic stuff here. Make sure to get plenty of natural, organic, high-quality and nutrient dense foods into your diet[3]! You can support your diet with smart supplementation. As opposed to popping a load of pills, I prefer bone broth. Bone broth allows you to take on fluids whilst also reaping additional benefits from the nutrients it contains.

For a start, it is packed with amino acids. Cysteine, glycine and glutamic acid are the building blocks for glutathione, a key antioxidant which protects us against oxidation, and eliminates toxins from our body[4]. Arginine, glutamine and proline, support the aforementioned benefits as well as helping to boost the health of your gut microbiome, strengthen the immune system and reduce inflammation. Furthermore, bone broth contains vitamins and minerals, including; boron, calcium, copper, iron, magnesium, potassium, phosphorus, vitamin A, vitamin B, vitamin D, vitamin D, and zinc, as well as gelatin and collagen. All vital for maintaining optimal health of the immune system.

And you can turbocharge your bone broth by adding garlic, which is known for having antiviral and antibacterial properties[5]. Add chilli to act as a natural decongestant[6]. Turmeric[7], cinnamon and ginger[8] can all help with reducing inflammation and speeding up your metabolism (to help flush out any illness). Beyond that, if you’re getting in your bone broth and supplementing with the aforementioned natural teas then you probably don’t need to go crazy on the off the shelf supplements (and requirements will vary from person to person depending on individual situation and goals).

Consider Switching to Intermittent Fasting

When animals get sick they stop eating, to focus on their rest and recovery. They divert all their energy towards the immune system to focus on healing the body. I’m a huge advocate of intermittent fasting, and have already written extensively on the main evidence backed benefits of intermittent fasting. Some of the key benefits include; boosting your biological processes, turbocharging your cells, and reducing the risk of disease.. There are plenty of studies emerging that are supporting these claims, as well as a whole host of other benefits.

When we eat food a lot of energy is diverted towards digestion. When we eat, the immune system is activated, increasing inflammation in a bid to ward off any unwanted microorganisms in our food. This uses up energy. By fasting we free up energy to fight of any dormant threats in our body. This also helps regulate the immune system, and there are plenty of studies linking fasting the the increased production of anti-inflammatory cytokines [9]. Finally, intermittent fasting has been shown to boost autophagy. This is the body’s method of killing off damaged cells. This eradicates cells that can cause inflammation, illness and disease[10].

Obviously committing to regular intermittent fasting is a rather dramatic lifestyle change. It is one that I made quite some time ago and I believe it is well worth it, but it’s up to you to decide on what works for you. When I do get sick, I will tend to fast quite extensively (largely because I just can’t face the prospect of eating). However, even if you don’t follow intermittent fasting on a regular basis, there is some evidence to suggest that fasting during illness can help with recovery[11]. Just make sure to do your research and be sensible!

Make Sure to Get Plenty of Exercise

Exercise has long been known to keep you strong, fit and healthy, and researchers have now started to look at links between exercise and the immune system. Physical activity may facilitate changes in white blood cells and antibodies, enabling them to circulate more quickly, and detect illnesses faster and more efficiently[12]. The rise in body temperature during and following exercise may mimic what happens when we have a fever and help the body to fight infection[13]. Finally, exercise may increase the release of immunoglobulins, which protect against illness, and slow down the release of stress hormones, some of which can cause illness[14].

Some studies suggest that over exercising, in terms of duration or intensity, can cause temporary reductions in immune system function. However, like with most things the overall evidence suggests that the positives of exercise outweigh the negatives. I think we should all be up and about, active, and getting plenty of exercise. Going back to our hunter gatherer days, that was how it was meant to be. There is plenty of evidence that shows that regular, moderate exercise contributes towards longevity.

However, one final point on exercise in relation to your immune system. When done over the long run it’ll give you major benefits. However, when you are actually feeling the onset of an illness then it’s time to wind down, and focus on rest and relaxation. In such a case then it is time to defer to the next point I will cover; sleep! When sick lay off the exercise and get plenty of rest and relaxation to give your body time to fight of illness and repair itself.

Get Plenty of Sleep to Aid Recovery

Whether you are fit and healthy, or under the weather, sleep is absolutely critical for a number of reasons. Human beings need a good consistent number of hours of sleep per night (around seven or eight). Sleep is the anabolic state that allows our body to rest and recover, by replenishing energy and regenerating tissue. Getting the right amount of sleep has been shown to have positive impacts on; the immune system[15], mood, concentration, productivity, and athletic performance[16].

Conversely, poor sleep has been associated with; a rise in cortisol levels and increased inflammation[15], high blood pressure[17], potential insulin resistance[18], weight gain[19], diabetes[20], cardiovascular disease[21], and mental illness[22]. For those that are interested in exploring sleep in much more detail, I have written comprehensive articles on the science of poor sleep and how to fix it and also, environment, behaviour and diet hacks to improve your sleep.

Getting plenty of sleep is going to keep you well rested, boost your immune system, and will help keep you fit and healthy. When you are unwell, an emphasis on rest and recovery is key. As mentioned, one of the key functions of sleep is for your body to shut down and work on any running repairs that are required. So, if you feel unwell, just accept that you need to slow down and devote some time to healing yourself. Let’s be honest, this is a free pass allowing you to chill out and stay in bed. So just accept it, don’t feel guilty, and focus on healing.

Use the Breath to Heal Yourself

Modern medicine is finally starting to pay attention to certain “alternative” healing practices. There is now strong evidence that some of these practices are very powerful. Wim Hof is famed for using breathwork, as part of a wider routine, to perform seemingly superhuman feats. In 2014, a group of subjects was trained in the Wim Hof method, and then injected with a strain of e.coli that normally causes severe flu like systems. Amazingly, they were able to fight off the effects of the endotoxin, whereas the control group exhibited the expected, strong flu like symptoms[23]. The late Dr. Konstantin Buteyko also used breathwork practices to fight off illness in patients[24].

There is a growing body of irrefutable evidence that we can use our breath to actively take control of our autonomic nervous system. This has the power to boost our immune system and fight off illness. In basic terms, these methods will typically revolve around periods of intermittent hyperventilation to induce respiratory alkalosis, interspersed with periods and hypoxia. This has been shown to allow the participant to voluntarily activate the sympathetic nervous system, leading to an ability to fight of the symptoms of illness, in part through increased levels of plasma epinephrine and anti-inflammatory cytokines, and a related reduction in pro-inflammatory mediators.

I’d love to delve deeper into the theory, science and practical applications of breathwork, and will do so in future articles. However, in this case I think it is enough to point to the evidence showing the power of the breath to support and control a healthy immune system to fight off illness. It is something I am a big advocate of, it’s a very interesting topic and I’d recommend exploring it in more detail. After all, we all breathe, so why not optimise what we do with our breath and really gain mastery and control of it for health and wellbeing.

Indulge in Regular Sauna Sessions

I love saunas! It is just such a nice way to relax after a hard day at work or a tough session in the gym. However, saunas also offer multiple health benefits, including the ability to strengthen your immune system when used correctly, alternating between hot and cold. Much like in our exercise example, saunas also raise your body temperature. This mimics the effects of a fever, causing your body to react accordingly. This results in an increase in white blood cells, lymphocyte, neutrophil, and basophil counts[25], offering direct evidence that saunas can activate and strengthen your immune system.

There are other studies that specifically focus on saunas and common illnesses. One such study found a direct link showing that regular sauna usage significantly reduces the occurrence of common colds and and can specifically lead to a 30% reduction in chance of catching a common cold or flu[26]. It does appear that further research is needed to fully validate some of these findings, but it’s a positive start, and new studies are being undertaken on a regular basis.

Finally, going back to the point about exercise, some of these studies also found that the benefits were greater in trained athletes. As with many things, I believe the sum is greater than the parts when it comes to bulletproofing your immune system, and clearly combining exercise and saunas is one such example. So, if like me, you love a sauna, then this is just one more reason to go ahead and spend some time getting a sweat on.

How to Reap Maximum Benefits

So, in simple terms, how you eat, move, sleep and breathe can have a big impact on boosting your immune system and minimising illness. It is also likely that the sum is greater than the parts. And arguably these are all just best practices that you should commit to, in order to optimise health and wellbeing beyond just supporting your immune system. By implementing as many of these practices into your life as possible, you’ll get the immune system benefits, but also so much more.

However, this only works if you are consistent. It’s no use waking up with a sore throat and then deciding to stop eating and jump in the sauna. Sure, there are quick fixes that help. For example, getting the right nutrition in and getting plenty of sleep will help. However, this works far better if you commit to altering your lifestyle over the long term. Only through a consistent approach can you be the best that you can possibly be. Once these things become habit, it is not so hard to commit to, and you will reap amazing benefits across multiple areas of physical and mental health and wellbeing.
